comments.commentBody: We need good governance more than ever from the EPA, our Representatives in our State and Federal Governments. The time is now ripe to show the American people that Government can work on behalf of the people.  Our Government’s mandate is to protect the people especially their health and their economic welfare.  We the people simply ask for good water and air. As human beings as well as all the other animals and plants on this earth that deserve life, we need good water and air to live. After all as President Obama had mentioned on February 23, 2011, referring to a Libyans cry, “We just want to be able to live like human beings,”  We, Americans who live in the states of Natural Gas Shale Plays also plead, “We just want to be able to live like human beings.” The economic interest of any company should not trump this basic tenet of life.

Ever since I stopped picking my nose, I rarely get sick. Who would of thought?

Wash your hands people. And do stay home when your sick if there is any way possible to do so.

Clearly, using anecdotal information to make decisions about the causes of illnesses is rather daft. The all out war on germs is short-sighted and problematic. Killing bugs just means that only the strongest bugs will survive, and those are really the ones you don't want.
Was such a relaxing place to stay- food is good, rooms are charming, and the owners left you alone to do your own thing. Would highly recommend this place!

comments.commentTitle: The best italian Restaurant in Bonn : Ristorante La Vita
comments.commentBody: We was staying  for 3 weeks in Bonn( Kongress) and visit 6 Times this wonderfull italian Restaurant " La Vita " Bonn for Dinner with fresh kitschen and the best italien food- best Pizza ( handmade! ) i ever eat! Greats from John

the funny thing is many folks commenting actually misread the tone of the article: if you read it a bit more carefully you'll see that it is _not_ advocating anything more than bringing along some hand sanitizer.  Other products are mentioned but not actually advocated.
Nice, clean, modest hotel with friendly staff. I recommend it for independent travelers. We liked it. Thank You.

To the person expressing concern over use of hand sanitizers - Hand sanitizers DO NOT USE antibiotics. That is why they are continually recommended. They use alcohol to kill germs which is an antiseptic. You are safe to use as much hand sanitizer as you want without contributing to super viruses. I totally agree with your concern on antibiotics being used in hand soap and all types of soaps where simply using soap and hot water as AS EFFECTIVE and do not pollute the water in the same way and hurt our ability to fight infections in the same way as inappropriate use of antibiotics. Yes to hand sanitizer - NO to adding antibiotics to soap (which already works to clean you).

I live in NYC and have been taking the subway to work for close to 30 years.  I also fly frequently both for work and pleasure and have a middle-school age child.  The last time I had a really bad cold/flu was back in the day when smoking was permitted both in the office and on airplanes. Of course, I am careful with hand-washing and using sanitizer but certainly not obsessive on either.

comments.commentTitle: If HOB was the "only" place open, I will "still" go elsewhere!
comments.commentBody:
We just returned on Sunday (19th) after a four day mini-vacation in Myrtle Beach. Of all the eating establishments patronized, "THIS" was by far the worst both in palpability and cost for the amount of food received! My wife ordered the so-called "Catch of the day", which turned out to be Mahi Mahi. The portion was about three ounces of blackened fish with cajun seasoning, about four ounces of mashed potatoes, and approximately a dozen small florets of broccoli. The price affixed to this paltry serving turned out to be $20. The reason that I state it this way as to the cost was due to the fact that the cost wasn't listed of the menu. I ordered the Jumbo blackened shrimp served on a bed of alfredo fettuccine. I was charged $18 for five shrimp, which turned out to be large instead of jumbo. The fettuccine was totally devoid of alfredo sauce and instead contained some sort of sweet red sauce that did not fit well with either the shrimp or the pasta. We also ordered a house salad with bleu cheese dressing and were charged $3 each with no concession considering the high prices of the entrees. Even though we relayed our disappointment to our waiter, at no time did any one on management staff stop by our table to inquire about our meal or to address our concerns that had previously been expressed to our waiter. During the course of sitting and partaking of our meal, a manager did pass by our table two times and neither of the two times did he acknowledge and/or ask us about how our meal was or if we had any concerns pertaining to our meal. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know when someone has indeed been ripped off and we certainly were taken advantage of in that respect or lack of respect. We will not be recommending HOB to anyone, as a matter-of-fact we'll be doing quite the opposite and listing our experience(s) on some of the consumer blogs that we list on.
I made several attempts to contact HOB “via” their web site (they make no provision for feedback and/ or complaints) and land line, all to no avail. They have a # listed in California, BUT, it rings and rings and no one answers. I even tried calling the # at the facility in Myrtle Beach and it goes to an announcement about events and upcoming events at said facility.
From my own WE experience, I recommend Ixchel Beach Hotel At http://www.ixchelbeachhotel.com

the next article will be able germs in subways
and then germs in your car
and then germs in hospitals
and then germs in your home
and then germs in you

Funny I should read this while laying in bed with a sore throat, chills and all that goes with it. I flew home from a few days ago from Los Angeles, so I guess this is all my own fault. I did not use seat pads or antiseptic wipes, did touch the tray table, my face, the magazine, the arm rest, the man next to me (not on purpose)and a bloody mary.  Next trip I will be sure to wrap myself in plastic and wear a gas mask.

It might be a good idea if the airlines supplied facemasks to sick hacking flyers. I took a flight were the passenger next to me was coughing the whole trip.  She didnt even cover her mouth. Next time I will bring my mask.

Don't read this if you are eating.

I'm not a germaphobe or overly fastidious, but . . .

On a bumpy flight about a year ago, the rickety tray catapulted a glass full of liquid and ice onto my lap, soaking said lap and the seat cushion on which it sat. The ice cubes slid from lap to seat, further soaking the cushion.

As I chased the ice and tried to mop up with the little cocktail napkin, I noticed that the wet seat cushions (coach-class fabric) were starting to smell to high heaven. I won't go into detail, but it was clear that many noxious substances had found their way onto that seat. A few of the odors, unfortunately, were identifiable. Others were mysterious, but equally repugnant.

Ick.

For the return flight, I bought myself a little travel blanket at the airport gift shop and spread it onto the seat. That blankie has been with me on every flight ever since.

This is the definitive film on the Kumbh Mela. Ira Cohen has captured the essence of the sadhus, their use of ganja and yogic practices in transcending the limits of the body in order to reach the divine. Having lived in India, Nepal and his native New York, Cohen is a poet and photographer who has lived among the divine, the mad, traveling the undercurrents of art and literature that drive our time. Seeing things from within, seeker and practitioner of holy madness himself, Cohen narrates the film with his visionary poetry and eye for the divine in madness, and the madness in the divine.

A nerd in Iowa who thinks selling insurance is a high calling, his seventh-grade teacher, a by-the-book roommate who wants to get to bed on time, a loudmouth fellow agent who fulfills every insurance agent stereotype, a gal looking for some fun away from her family and a street-walker---all set up at an insurance convention in a mid-priced hotel in Cedar Rapids. Is this supposed to be funny?

Take my word for it: This is a very funny film, mainly because it is so unexpected and the writing is so good.
It is not in the category of all-time great comedies like The Big Lebowski, The Producers, Young Frankenstein and Groundhog Day, but among second-tier small comedies, this is one of the best and most memorable---the Cedar Rapids, insurance convention version of Little Miss Sunshine.

"an occasionally marvelous restaurant"?? No Stars?? fish tag is the most innovative and exciting place in NYC right now. The lamb burger was made famous at Onera. For this alone the restaurant deserves a star. Psilakis created dishes never before seen. the Branzino with headcheese is a culinary experience. mussells with lamb, swordfish with sausage. Maybe it is Sifton that just does not get it. let the readers decide. 200 reviews on Opentable; 4 out of 5 stars..dont let this review discourage you from trying Fish Tag. Congrats Michael and Ryan..

Miss G...I've seen these front page posts of late and I'm careful to steer clear of them for my sanity (such as it is)! LOL I avoid any all all Mrs. Obama posts which seems to account for about 80% of the drama. I do get a kick out of Neto and EFrantz giving them some stick tho.. They always know just what to say.

I'm glad that you posted that piece from Robin Givhan because the issue is REAL and needs to be called out much more than it is. I'll read it and get back to you.

RC...of course there's anti-semitism and all other forms of prejudices in fashion. Why wouldn't there be? Fashion people, who usually are of a demographic minority themselves...ie women or gay men... aren't immune from bigotry than anyone else. In some ways, the idea that minorities are somehow immune from prejudices is part of the reason why bigotry is so rampant in fashion. People are too busy seeing their own perceived/real oppression to see their own biases towards people unlike themselves.p some are just more socially acceptable than others....think the vocal and constant rejection and stigmatizing of fat people, poor people, or short people, just for starters. Why are people so angry when race/religion/sexuality are the target rather than something else...say ugliness (perceived), weight, height, social class, etc...? I think it's because people are extremely complex beings able to condemn somethings while rationalizing others. IOW, like prejudice is a human trait...so is hypocrisy. It's apart of the human condition methinks. You'll have noticed that the anti Asian comments and the "I will kill you" part seems to have been lost in the sauce, right ? Needless to say, it shows quite well that all sorts of stinckin' thinkin' is afoot here, n'est-ce pas? This isn't just about Galliano...not a bit of it.

Fashion draws its ranks from the same pool as everything does...the society in which it operates. People have been trying to figure out since forever how to deal w/ such persistently entrenched attitudes, and so far....? I think things are better in some ways than in the past and keep improving, but in other ways I think people simply hide their thoughts/attitudes better than they used to. At some level tho, vilifying these attitudes doesn't make them go away, but simply go underground. That doesn't mean their affects are any less real tho. Air isn't visible, but you sure feel it when it kicks up.

In some ways I look at all this "shock" over Galliano's rants as being just more hypocrisy and melodrama. The big diff between him in this instance is that he was caught on tape and caught saying something specifically considered taboo in the place he said it...anti-semitism in modern France. If he had said that in the US or even the UK (w/ or w/o the tape), I wonder if it would have had the widespread impact that it has? Frankly, I doubt it.

Truthfully, I'm sure other prominent people in fashion have said as bad or worse and behaved as badly as Galliano, but there was no tape and/or people covered for them. I'm sure this was true for Galliano himself until last week. Much of the tone of these comments coming from the insiders has a whiff of "there but for the grace of God go I" (esp Karl Lagerfeld's super cynical statement). Hardly can he be so atypical of his peers, doncha think? People don't exist in vacuums RC.
RC/Miss G...I saw your comments left to me on the "Dior Dismisses Galliano" thread and responded to you. LOL...RC, you wanted Gallino talk, well I provided you some! ;o)

Miss G...I have no doubt that many DIY versions of Mugler were pretty darned good back in the day. Given that he was a couturier, it was about as affordable as any other couture...not very, but he definitely had a major "trickle down" influence (very appropriate for the 80s, eh?). For me the key is "back in the day" tho. Everything is always new to everybody at some point, but most people aren't presenting their version of it during PFW and asking big money for it (as I'm sure they will).

I just wonder why there's so much of a nostalgia trip w/ so many of "the kids" now? As much as I like Mugler, he was definitely of his time and that's partly why he's not around today designing for his label, but what has he to do w/ today? Fashion happens in it's time and context....at least much of the best fashion IMHO, tho many times it's because of that so many designers fade away. Why is everything seeming to be a redo of something long past? Again I ask, why bother w/ this when you can get a vintage Mugler (probably cheaper, if you're lucky) or DIY it yourself?

I'm a long time lover of designers Gareth Pugh, Olivier Theyskens, Rick Owens and the like as many here know. They all have touches of Mugler/Montana aesthetics IMHO but they put their own stamp on it and they have a contemporary feel. Many other designers are clearly inspired by them too (tho many times less obviously and less recognized as such), so it's not the aesthetic I have issue w/ but the execution and sense of the designer's personal vision/intent.

The Tut show was sent on the road by Hawass to get funds for the Cairo Museum.
Even after the millions earned , the place was a shambles, no good security, and poorly paid curators. Mr. Hawass who wrote a book with Susan Mubarak was certainly more concerned with self promotion than the well being of his workers or the collection. His narcissism knew no bounds.

He was an anti-Semitic jerk according to many published sources including wikipedia so good riddance to bad rubbish.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zahi_Hawass

"In January 2009, Hawass wrote in Al-Sharq Al-Awsat that "The concept of killing women, children and elderly people... seems to run in the blood of the Jews of Palestine" and that "the only thing that the Jews have learned from history is methods of tyranny and torment - so much so that they have become artists in this field." He explained that he was not referring to the Jews' "[original] faith" but rather "the faith that they forged and contaminated with their poison, which is aimed against all of mankind."[25]

In an interview on Egyptian television in April 2009, Hawass stated that "although Jews are few in number, they control the entire world" and commented on the "control they have" of the American economy and the media.[26][27][28] He later clarified that he was using rhetoric to explain political fragmentation among the Arabs and that he does not believe in a "Jewish conspiracy to control the world".[29]"
Historically speaking, the Grammys get it wrong as often as they get it right. Who cares?

that was both the first time I heard the song and watched the film.  I can honestly say that I truly did not see the video as a music video;  it was a short story, a novella of film, that obviously was in tune with the song.  can't wait to hear the rest.
Will there come a time when we can move beyond political correctness, and acknowledge that abortion too can be a loss which is grieved, sometimes for a long time?
